title: The Agricultural Revolution
description: Humans domesticate plants and animals, leading to the rise of agriculture.
explanation: Between c. 11,000 and 4,000 BCE, humans began domesticating plants and animals in various regions, leading to the rise of agriculture and the foundation for settled societies.

title: First Cities in Mesopotamia
description: The first cities emerge in Mesopotamia, including Eridu and Uruk.
explanation: Around 4000–3000 BCE, the first cities such as Eridu and Uruk emerged in Mesopotamia (modern Iraq), marking the beginning of urban civilization.

title: First Wheeled Vehicles
description: The first wheeled vehicles appear in Mesopotamia, Eastern Europe, and the Caucasus.
explanation: Around 3500 BCE, the invention of the wheel revolutionized transport and technology in Mesopotamia and surrounding regions.

title: First Writing Systems
description: Writing systems such as cuneiform and hieroglyphics appear in Mesopotamia and Egypt.
explanation: Around 3200 BCE, the first writing systems—cuneiform in Mesopotamia and hieroglyphics in Egypt—were developed, enabling record-keeping and complex administration.

title: Great Pyramid of Giza Built
description: The Great Pyramid of Giza is constructed for Pharaoh Khufu in Egypt.
explanation: Around 2560 BCE, the Great Pyramid of Giza was built as a tomb for Pharaoh Khufu, becoming one of the most iconic monuments of ancient Egypt.

title: Origin of Modern Alphabets
description: Proto-Sinaitic script emerges, leading to the development of modern alphabets.
explanation: Between c. 1850 and 800 BCE, the Proto-Sinaitic script gave rise to the Phoenician, Greek, and Roman alphabets, shaping written communication for millennia.

title: Code of Hammurabi Issued
description: Babylonian King Hammurabi issues one of the earliest legal codes.
explanation: Around 1754 BCE, Hammurabi, king of Babylon, issued the Code of Hammurabi, one of the earliest and most complete written legal codes.

title: Iron Age Begins
description: The spread of iron metallurgy marks the end of the Bronze Age and the start of the Iron Age.
explanation: Between c. 1200 and 500 BCE, knowledge of ironworking spread across the ancient world, ushering in the Iron Age and transforming societies.

title: Rise of Ancient Greek Civilization
description: The Greek city-states emerge, leading to a golden age of arts, philosophy, and democracy.
explanation: From c. 800 to 336 BCE, ancient Greece saw the rise of city-states, the birth of democracy, and major achievements in philosophy, science, and the arts.

title: Founding of Rome
description: Legendary founding of Rome, leading to the rise of Roman civilization.
explanation: According to legend, Rome was founded in 753 BCE, eventually becoming the center of one of history's greatest empires.

title: Life of the Buddha and Birth of Buddhism
description: Siddhartha Gautama (the Buddha) is born and Buddhism emerges in India.
explanation: Around 563–400 BCE, Siddhartha Gautama, known as the Buddha, lived and taught in India, founding Buddhism, one of the world's major religions.

title: Life of Confucius and Birth of Confucianism
description: Confucius is born and Confucianism emerges in China.
explanation: Between 551 and 479 BCE, Confucius lived and taught in China, establishing Confucianism, a philosophy that shaped East Asian societies for millennia.

title: Empire of Alexander the Great
description: Alexander the Great creates an immense empire across three continents.
explanation: From 336 to 323 BCE, Alexander the Great conquered much of the known world, spreading Greek culture and influence from Greece to Egypt, Persia, and India.

title: Unification of China under Qin Shi Huang
description: Qin Shi Huang unifies China and begins building the Great Wall.
explanation: Between 221 and 206 BCE, Qin Shi Huang unified China, established the Qin dynasty, and began construction of the Great Wall.

title: Birth of the Modern Calendar (Julian)
description: Julius Caesar reforms the Roman calendar, creating the Julian calendar.
explanation: In 45 BCE, Julius Caesar introduced the Julian calendar, a solar-based system that became the basis for the modern Gregorian calendar.

title: Life of Jesus and Birth of Christianity
description: Jesus is born and Christianity emerges in the Roman Empire.
explanation: Between c. 4 BCE and 70 CE, Jesus of Nazareth lived and taught, leading to the birth of Christianity, which became a major world religion.

title: Life of Muhammad and Birth of Islam
description: Muhammad is born and Islam emerges in Arabia.
explanation: Between 570 and 630 CE, Muhammad lived in Arabia, founded Islam, and united much of the Arabian Peninsula under a new religious and political order.

title: Battle of Tours-Poitiers
description: Franks defeat Umayyad Caliphate, halting Muslim advance into Western Europe.
explanation: In 732 CE, Charles Martel and the Franks defeated the Umayyad Caliphate at the Battle of Tours-Poitiers, halting the Muslim advance into Western Europe.

title: Charlemagne Crowned Holy Roman Emperor
description: Charlemagne is crowned as the first Holy Roman Emperor.
explanation: In 800 CE, Pope Leo III crowned Charlemagne as the first Holy Roman Emperor, marking the foundation of the Holy Roman Empire in Western Europe.

title: Invention and Use of Gunpowder
description: Chinese alchemists invent gunpowder, revolutionizing warfare.
explanation: Between c. 800 and 1300 CE, Chinese alchemists invented gunpowder, which spread across Eurasia and transformed military technology.

title: Norse Exploration of the North Atlantic
description: Norse explorers discover and colonize Iceland, Greenland, and North America.
explanation: Between c. 870 and 1000 CE, Norse explorers discovered and settled Iceland, Greenland, and briefly North America (Vinland).

title: Norman Conquest of England
description: William the Conqueror invades England and becomes king after the Battle of Hastings.
explanation: In 1066 CE, William the Conqueror led the Norman invasion of England, defeating King Harold II at the Battle of Hastings and becoming king, profoundly shaping English history.

title: First Western-Style University Established
description: The University of Bologna is founded in Italy, the first Western-style university.
explanation: In 1088 CE, the University of Bologna was founded in Italy, becoming the first Western-style university and a model for higher education in Europe.

title: The First Crusade
description: Pope Urban II calls for the First Crusade to the Holy Land.
explanation: Between 1095 and 1099 CE, the First Crusade was launched by Pope Urban II, resulting in the capture of Jerusalem and the establishment of Crusader states in the Levant.

title: Construction of Angkor Wat
description: King Suryavarman II builds Angkor Wat in Cambodia.
explanation: Around 1150 CE, King Suryavarman II of the Khmer Empire built Angkor Wat, a monumental temple complex in Cambodia.

title: Start of Shogunate Rule in Japan
description: Minamoto no Yoritomo establishes the Kamakura Shogunate in Japan.
explanation: In 1192 CE, Minamoto no Yoritomo overthrew the Taira emperor and established the Kamakura Shogunate, beginning centuries of shogunate rule in Japan.

title: Genghis Khan Founds the Mongol Empire
description: Genghis Khan unites the Mongols and begins building a vast empire.
explanation: From 1206 to 1260 CE, Genghis Khan and his successors built the Mongol Empire, the largest contiguous land empire in history.

title: Signing of the Magna Carta
description: English nobles force King John to sign the Magna Carta, limiting royal power.
explanation: In 1215 CE, English nobles forced King John to sign the Magna Carta, establishing the principle that the king was subject to the law.

title: Marco Polo's Travels to Asia
description: Venetian merchant Marco Polo travels through Asia, reaching China.
explanation: Between 1271 and 1300 CE, Marco Polo traveled through Asia, reaching China and later sharing his experiences in a widely read account.

title: Rise and Fall of the Aztec Civilization
description: The Aztec Empire rises in Mexico and falls to Spanish conquest.
explanation: From 1325 to 1521 CE, the Aztec Empire rose to power in Mexico before being conquered by Spanish forces led by Hernán Cortés.

title: The Black Death Devastates Europe
description: The bubonic plague kills one-third of Europe's population.
explanation: In 1347–1348, the Black Death (bubonic plague) swept through Europe, killing an estimated one-third of the population and profoundly impacting society and history.

title: The Renaissance Begins in Italy
description: A rediscovery of classical knowledge sparks innovations in arts and culture.
explanation: From c. 1350 to 1600, the Renaissance began in Florence, Italy, leading to major achievements in art, science, and culture across Europe.

title: The Inca Empire Rises in South America
description: The Inca people create an empire across the Andes.
explanation: From 1438 to 1533, the Inca Empire rose to dominate the Andes region of South America before falling to Spanish conquest.

title: Gutenberg Invents the Printing Press
description: Johannes Gutenberg invents a printing press using movable metal type.
explanation: Between 1440 and 1455, Johannes Gutenberg invented the printing press, revolutionizing the spread of information and literacy in Europe.

title: Ottoman Turks Take Constantinople
description: The fall of Constantinople marks the end of the Byzantine Empire.
explanation: In 1453, the Ottoman Turks captured Constantinople, ending the Byzantine Empire and shifting the balance of power in the region.

title: Columbus Arrives in the Americas
description: Christopher Columbus lands in the West Indies, beginning European conquest of the Americas.
explanation: In 1492, Christopher Columbus arrived in the West Indies, initiating European exploration and colonization of the Americas.

title: Vasco da Gama Finds Sea Route to India
description: Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama sails to India, opening a new trade route.
explanation: In 1498, Vasco da Gama reached India by sea, establishing a direct maritime route from Europe to Asia and boosting global trade.

title: The Slave Trade Begins in the Americas
description: Enslaved Africans are brought to the Americas for the first time.
explanation: From 1502 to 1619, enslaved Africans were forcibly brought to the Americas, beginning the transatlantic slave trade and shaping the history of the New World.

title: Martin Luther Starts the Protestant Reformation
description: Martin Luther sends his 95 Theses, challenging the Catholic Church.
explanation: In 1517, Martin Luther sent his 95 Theses to the Archbishop of Mainz, sparking the Protestant Reformation and transforming Christianity in Europe.

title: Suleiman the Magnificent Expands the Ottoman Empire
description: Suleiman rules the Ottoman Empire during a period of great expansion.
explanation: From 1520 to 1566, Suleiman the Magnificent ruled the Ottoman Empire, leading it through a period of territorial expansion and cultural achievement.

title: Magellan's Expedition Circumnavigates the Globe
description: Ferdinand Magellan's expedition is the first to circumnavigate the Earth.
explanation: In 1522, the expedition led by Ferdinand Magellan completed the first circumnavigation of the globe, proving the world was round and interconnected.

title: Copernicus Proposes Heliocentric Model
description: Nicolaus Copernicus publishes his heliocentric theory of the solar system.
explanation: In 1543, Nicolaus Copernicus published 'On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres,' proposing that the Earth revolves around the Sun.

title: Defeat of the Spanish Armada
description: England under Queen Elizabeth I defeats the Spanish Armada.
explanation: In 1588, the English navy, under Queen Elizabeth I, defeated the Spanish Armada, marking a turning point in European naval power.

title: Shakespeare Writes Hamlet
description: William Shakespeare writes the play Hamlet in England.
explanation: Between 1599 and 1601, William Shakespeare wrote Hamlet, one of the most influential works in English literature.

title: First Permanent English Settlement in America
description: English colonists establish Jamestown, Virginia.
explanation: In 1607, English colonists established Jamestown, Virginia, the first permanent English settlement in North America.

title: Galileo Publishes The Starry Messenger
description: Galileo Galilei announces astronomical discoveries using a telescope.
explanation: Between 1609 and 1610, Galileo Galilei published 'The Starry Messenger,' announcing discoveries that revolutionized astronomy.

title: English Civil War Begins
description: Civil war breaks out in England between Parliament and the monarchy.
explanation: From 1642 to 1660, England experienced a civil war between Parliament and the monarchy, leading to the temporary overthrow of the monarchy.

title: Construction of the Taj Mahal
description: Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan builds the Taj Mahal in India.
explanation: Between 1632 and 1653, Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan built the Taj Mahal, a monumental mausoleum in Agra, India.

title: The Power of Steam is Harnessed
description: Early steam engines are invented, leading to the Industrial Revolution.
explanation: Between 1663 and 1801, inventors in Britain and the US developed steam engines, paving the way for the Industrial Revolution.

title: Battle of Vienna Halts Ottoman Expansion
description: European forces defeat the Ottomans at Vienna, stopping their advance into Europe.
explanation: In 1683, the Holy Roman Empire and allies defeated the Ottoman Turks at the Battle of Vienna, halting Ottoman expansion into Western Europe.

title: Newton Publishes Principia Mathematica
description: Isaac Newton explains universal laws of motion and gravitation.
explanation: In 1687, Isaac Newton published 'Principia Mathematica,' laying the foundation for classical physics.

title: Innovations Spark the Industrial Revolution
description: British inventors develop key textile technologies.
explanation: Between 1733 and 1785, innovations in the British textile industry, such as the flying shuttle and spinning jenny, sparked the Industrial Revolution.

title: The Boston Tea Party
description: American colonists protest British taxes by throwing tea into Boston Harbor.
explanation: On December 16, 1773, American colonists protested British taxation by dumping tea into Boston Harbor, a key event leading to the American Revolution.

title: The American Revolution
description: The American colonies fight for independence from Britain.
explanation: From 1775 to 1783, the American colonies fought for and won independence from Britain, establishing the United States.

title: The French Revolution
description: Revolutionaries overthrow the monarchy and establish a republic in France.
explanation: From 1789 to 1799, the French Revolution overthrew the monarchy, established a republic, and profoundly changed France and the world.

title: The Medical Revolution: First Vaccine
description: Edward Jenner creates the first vaccine, for smallpox.
explanation: In 1796, Edward Jenner used cowpox virus to create the first vaccine, for smallpox, launching the field of immunology.

title: Birth of Rail Transport
description: Early steam locomotives are developed, leading to the railway age.
explanation: Between 1802 and 1830, inventors in Britain developed steam locomotives and railways, revolutionizing transportation.

title: Haitian Revolution and Independence
description: Enslaved people in Saint-Domingue establish the new nation of Haiti.
explanation: In 1804, after a successful revolution, enslaved people in Saint-Domingue established Haiti, the first independent Black republic.

title: The Napoleonic Wars Begin
description: Napoleon Bonaparte rises to power and leads France in a series of wars.
explanation: From 1799 to 1815, Napoleon Bonaparte led France in the Napoleonic Wars, reshaping Europe through conquest and reform.

title: Abolition of the Slave Trade in the UK
description: The United Kingdom abolishes the transatlantic slave trade.
explanation: In 1807, the United Kingdom passed legislation abolishing the transatlantic slave trade, a major step toward ending slavery worldwide.

title: Latin American Wars of Independence
description: Spain's colonies in Central and South America fight for and win independence.
explanation: From 1817 to 1825, Spain's colonies in Central and South America fought for and won independence, reshaping the Americas.

title: Invention of the Telegraph
description: The telegraph revolutionizes long-distance communication.
explanation: Between 1832 and 1840, inventors in Europe and the US developed the telegraph, revolutionizing long-distance communication.

title: The Communist Manifesto Published
description: Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels publish The Communist Manifesto.
explanation: In 1848, Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels published The Communist Manifesto, a foundational text for socialist and communist movements.

title: Darwin Publishes On the Origin of Species
description: Charles Darwin publishes his theory of evolution by natural selection.
explanation: In 1859, Charles Darwin published 'On the Origin of Species,' introducing the theory of evolution by natural selection.

title: The American Civil War Begins
description: Civil war breaks out in the United States over slavery and states' rights.
explanation: From 1860 to 1865, the United States fought a civil war over slavery and states' rights, resulting in the abolition of slavery.

title: The Meiji Restoration in Japan
description: Tokugawa Yoshinobu abdicates, ending shogun rule and restoring imperial power.
explanation: In 1867, the Meiji Restoration ended centuries of shogunate rule in Japan and restored imperial power, leading to rapid modernization.

title: Opening of the Suez Canal
description: The Suez Canal links the Mediterranean and Red Sea, transforming global trade.
explanation: In 1869, the Suez Canal opened, linking the Mediterranean and Red Sea and transforming global trade routes.

title: Alexander Graham Bell Patents the Telephone
description: Bell invents and patents the telephone, revolutionizing communication.
explanation: In 1876, Alexander Graham Bell patented the telephone, revolutionizing personal and business communication.

title: European Colonization of Africa Intensifies
description: European powers divide and colonize Africa at the Berlin Conference.
explanation: In the 1880s, European powers divided and colonized Africa at the Berlin Conference, reshaping the continent's political landscape.

title: Women's Suffrage Movement Achieves First Successes
description: New Zealand grants women the right to vote, followed by other nations.
explanation: Between 1893 and 1928, the women's suffrage movement achieved major successes, with New Zealand, Australia, Finland, the US, and the UK granting women the right to vote.

title: Invention of Radio Begins
description: Early experiments and inventions lay the groundwork for radio communication.
explanation: Between 1879 and 1901, inventors in Europe and the US developed the technology that led to the invention of radio.

title: Discovery of X-Rays
description: Wilhelm Röntgen discovers x-rays, revolutionizing medicine.
explanation: In 1895, Wilhelm Röntgen discovered x-rays, a breakthrough that revolutionized medical imaging and diagnosis.

title: Wright Brothers' First Powered Flight
description: Orville and Wilbur Wright achieve the first powered flight in the US.
explanation: On December 17, 1903, the Wright brothers achieved the first powered, controlled flight of an airplane in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.

title: Japan Defeats Russia in the Russo-Japanese War
description: Japan is recognized as a world power after defeating Russia.
explanation: From 1904 to 1905, Japan defeated Russia in the Russo-Japanese War, establishing itself as a major world power.

title: Einstein's Annus Mirabilis
description: Albert Einstein publishes groundbreaking papers, including special relativity.
explanation: In 1905, Albert Einstein published a series of papers, including the special theory of relativity and E=mc², revolutionizing physics.

title: World War I Begins
description: The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand triggers World War I.
explanation: In 1914, the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand led to the outbreak of World War I, a global conflict that reshaped the world order.

title: The Russian Revolution
description: Revolutionaries overthrow the Tsar and establish the Soviet Union.
explanation: From 1917 to 1922, the Russian Revolution overthrew the Tsar, led to civil war, and resulted in the creation of the Soviet Union.

title: Global Influenza Epidemic
description: A worldwide influenza epidemic kills millions of people.
explanation: In 1918, a global influenza epidemic (Spanish flu) killed an estimated 20 million people worldwide.

title: Invention of Television
description: Early television transmissions and inventions revolutionize communication.
explanation: Between 1925 and 1929, inventors in Europe, the US, and Japan developed television, revolutionizing mass communication.

title: The Great Depression Begins
description: The Wall Street Crash triggers a global economic depression.
explanation: In October 1929, the Wall Street Crash triggered the Great Depression, a worldwide economic crisis that lasted through the 1930s.

title: Rise of Adolf Hitler and the Nazis
description: Adolf Hitler forms the Nazi Party and rises to power in Germany.
explanation: From 1920 to 1939, Adolf Hitler formed the Nazi Party, rose to power, and led Germany into World War II.

title: Revolution in China
description: The Xinhai Revolution overthrows the Qing dynasty and establishes the Republic of China.
explanation: From 1911 to 1949, China underwent revolution, civil war, and the eventual establishment of the People's Republic of China.

title: World War II Begins
description: Germany invades Poland, triggering World War II.
explanation: In 1939, Germany invaded Poland, triggering World War II, the deadliest conflict in human history.

title: The United Nations is Formed
description: The United Nations is established to promote peace and cooperation.
explanation: In 1945–1946, the United Nations was established, bringing together nations to promote peace, security, and cooperation worldwide.

title: The Digital Revolution Begins
description: Charles Babbage designs the Difference Machine, the first concept of a computer.
explanation: From 1833 to 1965, inventors developed the first computers, leading to the digital revolution and the modern information age.

title: India Gains Independence from the UK
description: India becomes independent from British colonial rule.
explanation: In 1947, India gained independence from the UK, inspiring decolonization movements worldwide.

title: The Cold War Begins
description: Tensions rise between the US and Soviet Union, starting the Cold War.
explanation: From 1945 to 1989, the Cold War between the US and Soviet Union shaped global politics, economics, and military affairs.

title: Discovery of DNA Structure
description: James Watson and Francis Crick describe the double helix structure of DNA.
explanation: In 1953, James Watson and Francis Crick published their discovery of the double helix structure of DNA, revolutionizing biology and genetics.

title: U.S. Civil Rights Movement Begins
description: The U.S. Supreme Court rules segregated education unconstitutional.
explanation: From 1954 to 1968, the U.S. Civil Rights Movement fought for and achieved major advances in racial equality and civil rights.

title: The Vietnam War Begins
description: Conflict erupts in Vietnam, leading to decades of war.
explanation: From 1955 to 1975, the Vietnam War raged in Southeast Asia, with major involvement from the US and global consequences.

title: Sputnik Launches the Space Age
description: The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 1, the first artificial satellite.
explanation: On October 4, 1957, the Soviet Union launched Sputnik 1, the first artificial satellite, marking the beginning of the space age.

title: First Contraceptive Pill Approved
description: The U.S. FDA approves the first contraceptive pill.
explanation: On May 9, 1960, the U.S. Food & Drug Administration approved the first contraceptive pill, revolutionizing reproductive health.

title: Yuri Gagarin Becomes First Human in Space
description: Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin orbits the Earth.
explanation: In 1961, Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin became the first human to travel into space, orbiting the Earth aboard Vostok 1.

title: Assassination of John F. Kennedy
description: U.S. President John F. Kennedy is assassinated in Dallas, Texas.
explanation: On November 22, 1963, U.S. President John F. Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas, Texas, shocking the world.

title: Apollo 11 Moon Landing
description: Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin become the first humans to walk on the Moon.
explanation: On July 20, 1969, Apollo 11 astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first humans to set foot on the Moon, marking a major milestone in space exploration and human achievement.

title: The Birth of the Internet Begins
description: Early computer networks are developed, leading to the Internet.
explanation: From 1965 to 1995, the development of computer networks led to the creation of the Internet, transforming global communication.

title: The Cold War Ends and Berlin Wall Falls
description: The Berlin Wall falls, symbolizing the end of the Cold War.
explanation: On November 9, 1989, the Berlin Wall fell, symbolizing the end of the Cold War and the reunification of Germany.

title: End of Apartheid in South Africa
description: Nelson Mandela is released and apartheid ends in South Africa.
explanation: From 1990 to 1994, Nelson Mandela was released from prison and apartheid ended in South Africa, leading to multiracial democracy.

title: September 11 Attacks and War on Terror
description: Al Qaeda terrorists attack the US, leading to the War on Terror.
explanation: On September 11, 2001, Al Qaeda terrorists attacked New York City and Washington, D.C., leading to the US War on Terror.

title: Justinian I Closes the Academy at Athens
description: The last pagan philosophical school in Athens is closed by order of the Byzantine Emperor.
explanation: In 529 CE, Emperor Justinian I closed the Academy at Athens, ending a centuries-old center of classical learning and marking a shift toward Christian dominance in education.

title: Birth of Muhammad
description: Muhammad, founder of Islam, is born in Mecca.
explanation: Around 570 CE, Muhammad was born in Mecca. His teachings would lead to the rise of Islam, profoundly shaping world history.

title: The Hijra: Muhammad's Migration to Medina
description: Muhammad and his followers migrate from Mecca to Medina, marking the start of the Islamic calendar.
explanation: In 622 CE, Muhammad and his followers migrated from Mecca to Medina, an event known as the Hijra, which marks the beginning of the Islamic calendar.

title: Battle of Tours
description: Frankish forces halt the advance of the Umayyad Caliphate into Western Europe.
explanation: In 732 CE, Charles Martel led the Franks to victory over the Umayyad Caliphate at the Battle of Tours, stopping Muslim expansion into Western Europe.

title: Charlemagne Crowned Emperor
description: Charlemagne is crowned Holy Roman Emperor by Pope Leo III.
explanation: On Christmas Day, 800 CE, Charlemagne was crowned Holy Roman Emperor, reviving the imperial tradition in Western Europe.

title: Treaty of Verdun Divides the Carolingian Empire
description: Charlemagne's empire is split among his grandsons, shaping the future of Europe.
explanation: In 843 CE, the Treaty of Verdun divided the Carolingian Empire into three kingdoms, laying the groundwork for modern France and Germany.

title: Founding of Kievan Rus'
description: The state of Kievan Rus' is established, precursor to Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus.
explanation: In 862 CE, the state of Kievan Rus' was founded by Norse settlers, becoming a major medieval power in Eastern Europe.

title: Christianization of Kievan Rus'
description: Vladimir the Great adopts Christianity for his people, spreading Orthodox Christianity in Eastern Europe.
explanation: In 988 CE, Vladimir the Great converted to Christianity and baptized Kievan Rus', establishing Orthodox Christianity in the region.

title: The Great Schism
description: The Christian Church splits into Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox branches.
explanation: In 1054 CE, the Great Schism divided Christianity into the Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox Churches, a split that endures to this day.

title: Norman Conquest of England
description: William the Conqueror defeats Harold II at the Battle of Hastings and becomes king of England.
explanation: In 1066 CE, William the Conqueror led the Normans to victory at Hastings, transforming English society, language, and governance.

title: Battle of Manzikert
description: Seljuk Turks defeat the Byzantine Empire, opening Anatolia to Turkish settlement.
explanation: In 1071 CE, the Seljuk Turks defeated the Byzantines at Manzikert, leading to Turkish dominance in Anatolia and weakening Byzantine power.

title: Pope Urban II Calls the First Crusade
description: Pope Urban II urges Christians to reclaim the Holy Land, launching the Crusades.
explanation: In 1095 CE, Pope Urban II called for the First Crusade, initiating a series of religious wars between Christians and Muslims over the Holy Land.

title: Concordat of Worms Ends Investiture Controversy
description: An agreement between the Pope and Holy Roman Emperor resolves a major church-state conflict.
explanation: In 1122 CE, the Concordat of Worms ended the Investiture Controversy, clarifying the roles of church and state in appointing bishops.

title: Second Crusade Launched
description: European leaders launch the Second Crusade to the Holy Land.
explanation: In 1147 CE, European monarchs launched the Second Crusade in response to the fall of Edessa, but the campaign ultimately failed to achieve its goals.

title: Saladin Recaptures Jerusalem
description: Muslim leader Saladin retakes Jerusalem from the Crusaders.
explanation: In 1187 CE, Saladin recaptured Jerusalem from the Crusaders, prompting the launch of the Third Crusade by European powers.

title: Fourth Crusade Sacks Constantinople
description: Crusaders capture and sack Constantinople, weakening the Byzantine Empire.
explanation: In 1204 CE, Crusaders diverted from their original goal and sacked Constantinople, severely weakening the Byzantine Empire.

title: Magna Carta Signed
description: King John of England signs the Magna Carta, limiting royal authority.
explanation: In 1215 CE, King John of England was forced to sign the Magna Carta, establishing the principle that the king was subject to the law.

title: Mongol Invasion of Europe
description: Mongol armies defeat European forces at the Battle of Legnica.
explanation: In 1241 CE, Mongol armies defeated European forces at Legnica, demonstrating the reach and power of the Mongol Empire.

title: First Mongol Invasion of Japan
description: Mongol fleets attempt to invade Japan but are repelled by storms and defenders.
explanation: In 1274 CE, the Mongols launched their first invasion of Japan, but storms (kamikaze) and Japanese resistance forced their retreat.

title: Fall of Acre Ends Crusader States
description: The last Crusader stronghold in the Holy Land falls to Muslim forces.
explanation: In 1291 CE, the city of Acre fell to Muslim forces, marking the end of Crusader states in the Holy Land.

title: Pope Boniface VIII Issues Unam Sanctam
description: A papal bull asserts papal supremacy over secular rulers.
explanation: In 1302 CE, Pope Boniface VIII issued Unam Sanctam, declaring the supremacy of the pope over secular authorities, intensifying church-state conflicts.

title: Start of the Hundred Years' War
description: A prolonged conflict begins between England and France over succession to the French throne.
explanation: In 1337 CE, the Hundred Years' War began between England and France, a series of conflicts that shaped both nations for generations.

title: The Black Death Arrives in Europe
description: The bubonic plague devastates Europe, killing millions.
explanation: In 1347 CE, the Black Death reached Europe, causing massive population loss and social upheaval.

title: The Western Schism Begins
description: Rival popes are elected, dividing the Catholic Church.
explanation: In 1378 CE, the Western Schism began, with multiple claimants to the papacy, splitting the Catholic Church for decades.

title: The Peasants' Revolt in England
description: English peasants rise up against taxes and feudal oppression.
explanation: In 1381 CE, the Peasants' Revolt erupted in England, challenging feudal structures and royal authority.

title: Battle of Agincourt
description: English forces achieve a major victory over the French in the Hundred Years' War.
explanation: In 1415 CE, the English army, led by Henry V, defeated a much larger French force at Agincourt, a turning point in the Hundred Years' War.

title: Joan of Arc Executed
description: Joan of Arc is burned at the stake after leading French forces to key victories.
explanation: In 1431 CE, Joan of Arc was executed for heresy after playing a crucial role in lifting the siege of Orléans and inspiring French resistance.

title: Fall of Constantinople
description: The Ottoman Empire captures Constantinople, ending the Byzantine Empire.
explanation: In 1453 CE, the Ottomans captured Constantinople, marking the end of the Byzantine Empire and a major shift in world history.

title: Marriage of Ferdinand and Isabella Unites Spain
description: The union of Castile and Aragon paves the way for a unified Spain.
explanation: In 1469 CE, the marriage of Ferdinand of Aragon and Isabella of Castile united Spain's largest kingdoms, leading to the rise of a powerful Spanish state.

title: Columbus Reaches the Americas
description: Christopher Columbus lands in the New World, initiating European colonization.
explanation: In 1492 CE, Columbus reached the Americas, beginning a new era of global exploration and exchange.

title: Umayyad Conquest of Hispania
description: Muslim forces cross into Iberia, beginning centuries of Islamic rule in Spain.
explanation: In 711 CE, Umayyad armies crossed the Strait of Gibraltar and began the conquest of the Iberian Peninsula, establishing Al-Andalus.

title: Viking Raid on Lindisfarne
description: Vikings attack the monastery at Lindisfarne, marking the start of the Viking Age.
explanation: In 793 CE, Vikings raided the monastery at Lindisfarne, England, signaling the beginning of the Viking Age in Europe.

title: Carolingian Renaissance Begins
description: A revival of learning and culture flourishes under Charlemagne.
explanation: Around 800 CE, Charlemagne's court fostered a revival of learning, arts, and culture known as the Carolingian Renaissance.

title: Ottonian Dynasty Rises in Germany
description: Henry the Fowler becomes king, founding the Ottonian dynasty.
explanation: In 919 CE, Henry the Fowler became king of East Francia, founding the Ottonian dynasty and strengthening the Holy Roman Empire.

title: Holy Roman Empire Established
description: Otto I is crowned emperor, reviving the imperial title in Western Europe.
explanation: In 962 CE, Otto I was crowned Holy Roman Emperor, reestablishing the imperial tradition in Western Europe.

title: Leif Erikson Reaches North America
description: Norse explorer Leif Erikson lands in Vinland, likely Newfoundland.
explanation: Around 1000 CE, Leif Erikson led Norse expeditions to North America, centuries before Columbus.

title: Invention of Movable Type in China
description: Bi Sheng invents movable clay type, revolutionizing printing in East Asia.
explanation: Around 1040 CE, Bi Sheng in China invented movable type printing, a major technological advance.

title: Crusaders Capture Jerusalem
description: First Crusade forces seize Jerusalem from Muslim control.
explanation: In 1099 CE, Crusaders captured Jerusalem, establishing a Christian kingdom in the Holy Land.

title: Battle of Legnano
description: Italian city-states defeat the Holy Roman Emperor, asserting their independence.
explanation: In 1176 CE, the Lombard League of Italian cities defeated Emperor Frederick Barbarossa at Legnano, strengthening communal independence.

title: Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa
description: Christian forces win a decisive victory over the Almohads in Spain.
explanation: In 1212 CE, Christian armies defeated the Almohad Caliphate at Las Navas de Tolosa, a turning point in the Reconquista.

title: Death of Genghis Khan
description: Genghis Khan dies, leaving a vast Mongol Empire to his successors.
explanation: In 1227 CE, Genghis Khan died, and his empire was divided among his sons, continuing Mongol expansion across Eurasia.

title: Battle of Ain Jalut
description: Mamluk forces defeat the Mongols, halting their advance into Egypt.
explanation: In 1260 CE, the Mamluks defeated the Mongols at Ain Jalut, stopping Mongol expansion into the Middle East.

title: Yuan Dynasty Established in China
description: Kublai Khan completes the Mongol conquest of China, founding the Yuan dynasty.
explanation: In 1279 CE, Kublai Khan established the Yuan dynasty after conquering the Song, bringing all of China under Mongol rule.

title: Ottoman Empire Founded
description: Osman I founds the Ottoman dynasty, which will rule for centuries.
explanation: In 1299 CE, Osman I founded the Ottoman dynasty, beginning the rise of the Ottoman Empire.

title: Avignon Papacy Begins
description: The papacy moves from Rome to Avignon, France, for nearly 70 years.
explanation: In 1309 CE, the papacy relocated to Avignon, France, where it remained until 1377, a period known as the Avignon Papacy.

title: Hundred Years' War Begins
description: A long conflict starts between England and France over the French throne.
explanation: In 1337 CE, the Hundred Years' War began, a series of conflicts between England and France that lasted until 1453.

title: Golden Bull Issued in the Holy Roman Empire
description: The Golden Bull defines the constitutional structure of the Holy Roman Empire.
explanation: In 1356 CE, the Golden Bull was issued, establishing rules for electing the Holy Roman Emperor and shaping imperial governance.

title: Battle of Kosovo
description: Ottoman and Serbian forces clash in a pivotal battle for the Balkans.
explanation: In 1389 CE, the Battle of Kosovo saw Ottoman and Serbian armies fight for control of the Balkans, influencing the region's future.

title: Battle of Grunwald
description: Polish-Lithuanian forces defeat the Teutonic Knights in one of medieval Europe's largest battles.
explanation: In 1410 CE, the Polish-Lithuanian alliance defeated the Teutonic Knights at Grunwald, shifting the balance of power in Eastern Europe.

title: Wars of the Roses Begin in England
description: A dynastic conflict erupts between the houses of Lancaster and York.
explanation: In 1455 CE, the Wars of the Roses began, a series of civil wars for the English throne between the houses of Lancaster and York.
